**Progesterone** is an [endogenous](/wiki/Endogenous "Endogenous")
[steroid](/wiki/Steroid "Steroid") and [progestogen](/wiki/Progestogen
"Progestogen") [sex hormone](/wiki/Sex_hormone "Sex hormone") involved in the
[menstrual cycle](/wiki/Menstrual_cycle "Menstrual cycle"),
[pregnancy](/wiki/Pregnancy "Pregnancy"), and
[embryogenesis](/wiki/Embryogenesis "Embryogenesis") of humans and other
species.[11] It belongs to a group of steroid hormones called the
[progestogens](/wiki/Progestogen "Progestogen"),[11] and is the major
progestogen in the body. Progesterone is also a crucial [metabolic
intermediate](/wiki/Metabolic_intermediate "Metabolic intermediate") in the
production of other endogenous [steroids](/wiki/Steroid "Steroid"), including
the [sex hormones](/wiki/Sex_hormone "Sex hormone") and the
[corticosteroids](/wiki/Corticosteroid "Corticosteroid"), and plays an
important role in brain function as a [neurosteroid](/wiki/Neurosteroid
"Neurosteroid").[12]

## Biological
activity[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Progesterone&action=edit&section=1 "Edit
section: Biological activity")]

Progesterone is the most important progestogen in the body, the result of its
action as a potent [agonist](/wiki/Agonist "Agonist") of the [nuclear
progesterone receptor](/wiki/Progesterone_receptor "Progesterone receptor")
(nPR) (with an [affinity](/wiki/Affinity_\(pharmacology\) "Affinity
\(pharmacology\)") of KD = 1 nM).[13][11] In addition, progesterone is an
agonist of the more recently discovered [membrane progesterone
receptors](/wiki/Membrane_progesterone_receptor "Membrane progesterone
receptor") (mPRs),[14] as well as a ligand of the [PGRMC1](/wiki/PGRMC1
"PGRMC1") (progesterone receptor membrane component 1).[15] Moreover,
progesterone is also known to be an antagonist of the
[sigma](/wiki/Sigma_receptor "Sigma receptor") [σ1
receptor](/wiki/Sigma-1_receptor "Sigma-1 receptor"),[16][17] a [negative
allosteric modulator](/wiki/Negative_allosteric_modulator "Negative allosteric
modulator") of [nicotinic acetylcholine
receptors](/wiki/Nicotinic_acetylcholine_receptor "Nicotinic acetylcholine
receptor"),[12] and a potent antagonist of the [mineralocorticoid
receptor](/wiki/Mineralocorticoid_receptor "Mineralocorticoid receptor")
(MR).[18] Progesterone prevents MR activation by binding to this receptor with
an affinity exceeding even those of [aldosterone](/wiki/Aldosterone
"Aldosterone") and [glucocorticoids](/wiki/Glucocorticoid "Glucocorticoid")
such as [cortisol](/wiki/Cortisol "Cortisol") and
[corticosterone](/wiki/Corticosterone "Corticosterone"),[18] and produces
[antimineralocorticoid](/wiki/Antimineralocorticoid "Antimineralocorticoid")
effects, such as [natriuresis](/wiki/Natriuresis "Natriuresis"), at
physiological concentrations.[19] In addition, progesterone binds to and
behaves as a [partial agonist](/wiki/Partial_agonist "Partial agonist") of the
[glucocorticoid receptor](/wiki/Glucocorticoid_receptor "Glucocorticoid
receptor") (GR), albeit with very low potency ([EC50](/wiki/EC50 "EC50")
>100-fold less relative to [cortisol](/wiki/Cortisol "Cortisol")).[20][21]

Progesterone, through its [neurosteroid](/wiki/Neurosteroid "Neurosteroid")
[active metabolites](/wiki/Active_metabolite "Active metabolite") such as
[5α-dihydroprogesterone](/wiki/5%CE%B1-dihydroprogesterone
"5α-dihydroprogesterone") and [allopregnanolone](/wiki/Allopregnanolone
"Allopregnanolone"), acts indirectly as a [positive allosteric
modulator](/wiki/Positive_allosteric_modulator "Positive allosteric
modulator") of the [GABAA receptor](/wiki/GABAA_receptor "GABAA
receptor").[22]

Progesterone and some of its metabolites, such as
[5β-dihydroprogesterone](/wiki/5%CE%B2-dihydroprogesterone
"5β-dihydroprogesterone"), are agonists of the [pregnane X
receptor](/wiki/Pregnane_X_receptor "Pregnane X receptor") (PXR),[23] albeit
weakly so ([EC50](/wiki/EC50 "EC50") >10 µM).[24] In accordance, progesterone
[induces](/wiki/Enzyme_inducer "Enzyme inducer") several
[hepatic](/wiki/Hepatic "Hepatic") [cytochrome P450](/wiki/Cytochrome_P450
"Cytochrome P450") [enzymes](/wiki/Enzyme "Enzyme"),[25] such as
[CYP3A4](/wiki/CYP3A4 "CYP3A4"),[26][27] especially during
[pregnancy](/wiki/Pregnancy "Pregnancy") when concentrations are much higher
than usual.[28] Perimenopausal women have been found to have greater CYP3A4
activity relative to men and postmenopausal women, and it has been inferred
that this may be due to the higher progesterone levels present in
perimenopausal women.[26]

Progesterone modulates the activity of
[CatSper](/wiki/Cation_channels_of_sperm "Cation channels of sperm") (cation
channels of sperm) [voltage-gated](/wiki/Voltage-gated_ion_channel "Voltage-
gated ion channel") Ca2+ channels. Since eggs release progesterone, sperm may
use progesterone as a homing signal to swim toward eggs
([chemotaxis](/wiki/Chemotaxis "Chemotaxis")). As a result, it has been
suggested that substances that block the progesterone binding site on CatSper
channels could potentially be used in [male
contraception](/wiki/Male_contraception "Male contraception").[29][30]

## Biological
function[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Progesterone&action=edit&section=2 "Edit
section: Biological function")]

### Hormonal
interactions[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Progesterone&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Hormonal interactions")]

Progesterone has a number of physiological effects that are amplified in the
presence of [estrogens](/wiki/Estrogen "Estrogen"). Estrogens through
[estrogen receptors](/wiki/Estrogen_receptor "Estrogen receptor") (ERs) induce
or [upregulate](/wiki/Upregulation "Upregulation") the
[expression](/wiki/Gene_expression "Gene expression") of the PR.[31] One
example of this is in [breast](/wiki/Breast "Breast") tissue, where estrogens
allow progesterone to mediate [lobuloalveolar](/wiki/Lobuloalveolar
"Lobuloalveolar") development.[32][33][34]

Elevated levels of progesterone potently reduce the sodium-retaining activity
of aldosterone, resulting in natriuresis and a reduction in extracellular
fluid volume. Progesterone withdrawal, on the other hand, is associated with a
temporary increase in sodium retention (reduced natriuresis, with an increase
in extracellular fluid volume) due to the compensatory increase in aldosterone
production, which combats the blockade of the mineralocorticoid receptor by
the previously elevated level of progesterone.[35]

### Reproductive
system[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Progesterone&action=edit&section=4 "Edit
section: Reproductive system")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/83/Endometrium_ocp_use3.jpg/225px-
Endometrium_ocp_use3.jpg)](/wiki/File:Endometrium_ocp_use3.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Endometrium_ocp_use3.jpg "Enlarge")

[Micrograph](/wiki/Micrograph "Micrograph") showing changes to the
[endometrium](/wiki/Endometrium "Endometrium") due to progesterone
([decidualization](/wiki/Decidualization "Decidualization")) [H&E
stain](/wiki/H%26E_stain "H&E stain").

Progesterone has key effects via non-genomic signalling on human sperm as they
migrate through the female tract before [fertilization](/wiki/Fertilization
"Fertilization") occurs, though the receptor(s) as yet remain
unidentified.[36] Detailed characterisation of the events occurring in sperm
in response to progesterone has elucidated certain events including
intracellular calcium transients and maintained changes,[37] slow calcium
oscillations,[38] now thought to possibly regulate motility.[39] It is
produced by the ovaries.[40] Interestingly, progesterone has also been shown
to demonstrate effects on octopus spermatozoa.[41]

Progesterone is sometimes called the "hormone of pregnancy",[42] and it has
many roles relating to the development of the fetus:

  * Progesterone converts the [endometrium](/wiki/Endometrium "Endometrium") to its secretory stage to prepare the uterus for implantation. At the same time progesterone affects the vaginal [epithelium](/wiki/Epithelium "Epithelium") and [cervical mucus](/wiki/Cervix#Cervical_mucus "Cervix"), making it thick and impenetrable to [sperm](/wiki/Sperm "Sperm"). Progesterone is anti-[mitogenic](/wiki/Mitosis "Mitosis") in endometrial epithelial cells, and as such, mitigates the tropic effects of [estrogen](/wiki/Estrogen "Estrogen").[43] If pregnancy does not occur, progesterone levels will decrease, leading, in the human, to [menstruation](/wiki/Menstruation "Menstruation"). Normal menstrual bleeding is progesterone-withdrawal bleeding. If ovulation does not occur and the [corpus luteum](/wiki/Corpus_luteum "Corpus luteum") does not develop, levels of progesterone may be low, leading to [anovulatory dysfunctional uterine bleeding.](/wiki/Dysfunctional_uterine_bleeding#Anovulatory_DUB "Dysfunctional uterine bleeding")
  * During implantation and [gestation](/wiki/Gestation "Gestation"), progesterone appears to decrease the maternal [immune](/wiki/Immune_system "Immune system") response to allow for the acceptance of the pregnancy.
  * Progesterone decreases contractility of the uterine [smooth muscle](/wiki/Smooth_muscle "Smooth muscle").[42]
  * In addition progesterone inhibits [lactation](/wiki/Lactation "Lactation") during pregnancy. The fall in progesterone levels following delivery is one of the triggers for milk production.
  * A drop in progesterone levels is possibly one step that facilitates the onset of [labor](/wiki/Labor_\(childbirth\) "Labor \(childbirth\)").

The [fetus](/wiki/Fetus "Fetus") [metabolizes](/wiki/Metabolize "Metabolize")
placental progesterone in the production of [adrenal](/wiki/Adrenal "Adrenal")
steroids.

### Breasts[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Progesterone&action=edit&section=5 "Edit
section: Breasts")]

See also: [Breast development §
Biochemistry](/wiki/Breast_development#Biochemistry "Breast development")

#### Lobuloalveolar
development[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Progesterone&action=edit&section=6 "Edit
section: Lobuloalveolar development")]

Progesterone plays an important role in [breast
development](/wiki/Breast_development "Breast development") in women. In
conjunction with [prolactin](/wiki/Prolactin "Prolactin"), it mediates
[lobuloalveolar](/wiki/Mammary_alveolus "Mammary alveolus") maturation of the
[mammary glands](/wiki/Mammary_gland "Mammary gland") during pregnancy to
allow for [milk production](/wiki/Milk_production "Milk production") and thus
[lactation](/wiki/Lactation "Lactation") and
[breastfeeding](/wiki/Breastfeeding "Breastfeeding") of
[offspring](/wiki/Offspring "Offspring") following
[parturition](/wiki/Parturition "Parturition") (childbirth).[44]
[Estrogen](/wiki/Estrogen "Estrogen") induces expression of the PR in breast
tissue and hence progesterone is dependent on estrogen to mediate
lobuloalveolar development.[32][33][34] It has been found that
[RANKL](/wiki/Receptor_activator_of_nuclear_factor_kappa-B_ligand "Receptor
activator of nuclear factor kappa-B ligand") is a critical downstream mediator
of progesterone-induced lobuloalveolar maturation.[45] RANKL [knockout
mice](/wiki/Knockout_mice "Knockout mice") show an almost identical mammary
phenotype to PR knockout mice, including normal mammary ductal development but
complete failure of the development of lobuloalveolar structures.[45]

#### Ductal
development[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Progesterone&action=edit&section=7 "Edit
section: Ductal development")]

Though to a far lesser extent than estrogen, which is the major mediator of
mammary ductal development (via the [ERα](/wiki/Estrogen_receptor_alpha
"Estrogen receptor alpha")),[46][47] progesterone has been found to be
involved in ductal development of the mammary glands to some extent as
well.[48] PR knockout mice or mice treated with the [PR
antagonist](/wiki/Antiprogestogen "Antiprogestogen")
[mifepristone](/wiki/Mifepristone "Mifepristone") show delayed although
otherwise normal mammary ductal development at puberty.[48] In addition, mice
modified to have [overexpression](/wiki/Overexpression "Overexpression") of
[PRA](/wiki/Progesterone_receptor_A "Progesterone receptor A") display ductal
hyperplasia,[45] and progesterone induces ductal growth in the mouse mammary
gland.[48] Progesterone mediates ductal development mainly via induction of
the [expression](/wiki/Gene_expression "Gene expression") of
[amphiregulin](/wiki/Amphiregulin "Amphiregulin"), the same [growth
factor](/wiki/Growth_factor "Growth factor") that estrogen primarily induces
the expression of to mediate ductal development.[48] These animal findings
suggest that, while not essential for full mammary ductal development,
progesterone seems to play a potentiating or accelerating role in estrogen-
mediated mammary ductal development.[48]

#### Breast cancer
risk[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Progesterone&action=edit&section=8 "Edit
section: Breast cancer risk")]

Progesterone also appears to be involved in the
[pathophysiology](/wiki/Pathophysiology "Pathophysiology") of [breast
cancer](/wiki/Breast_cancer "Breast cancer"), though its role, and whether it
is a promoter or inhibitor of breast cancer risk, has not been fully
elucidated.[49] In any case, while most synthetic progestins like
[medroxyprogesterone acetate](/wiki/Medroxyprogesterone_acetate
"Medroxyprogesterone acetate") have been found to significantly increase the
risk of breast cancer in postmenopausal women in combination with estrogen as
a component of [hormone replacement therapy](/wiki/Hormone_replacement_therapy
"Hormone replacement therapy"), the combination of natural progesterone (or
the atypical progestin [dydrogesterone](/wiki/Dydrogesterone
"Dydrogesterone")) with estrogen has been found not to do so.[50][51]

### Skin health[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Progesterone&action=edit&section=9
"Edit section: Skin health")]

The [estrogen receptor](/wiki/Estrogen_receptor "Estrogen receptor"), as well
as the [progesterone receptor](/wiki/Progesterone_receptor "Progesterone
receptor"), have been detected in the [skin](/wiki/Human_skin "Human skin"),
including in [keratinocytes](/wiki/Keratinocyte "Keratinocyte") and
[fibroblasts](/wiki/Fibroblast "Fibroblast").[52][53] At
[menopause](/wiki/Menopause "Menopause") and thereafter, decreased levels of
female [sex hormones](/wiki/Sex_hormone "Sex hormone") result in
[atrophy](/wiki/Atrophy "Atrophy"), thinning, and increased
[wrinkling](/wiki/Wrinkling "Wrinkling") of the skin and a reduction in skin
[elasticity](/wiki/Elasticity_\(physics\) "Elasticity \(physics\)"), firmness,
and strength.[52][53] These skin changes constitute an acceleration in [skin
aging](/wiki/Human_skin#Aging "Human skin") and are the result of decreased
[collagen](/wiki/Collagen "Collagen") content, irregularities in the
[morphology](/wiki/Morphology_\(biology\) "Morphology \(biology\)") of
[epidermal](/wiki/Epidermis_\(skin\) "Epidermis \(skin\)") [skin
cells](/wiki/Skin_cell "Skin cell"), decreased [ground
substance](/wiki/Ground_substance "Ground substance") between [skin
fibers](/wiki/Skin_fiber "Skin fiber"), and reduced
[capillaries](/wiki/Capillary "Capillary") and [blood flow](/wiki/Blood_flow
"Blood flow").[52][53] The skin also becomes more [dry](/wiki/Dry_skin "Dry
skin") during menopause, which is due to reduced skin
[hydration](/wiki/Tissue_hydration "Tissue hydration") and [surface
lipids](/wiki/Sebum "Sebum") (sebum production).[52] Along with chronological
aging and photoaging, estrogen deficiency in menopause is one of the three
main factors that predominantly influences skin aging.[52]

HRT, consisting of systemic treatment with estrogen alone or in combination
with a progestogen, has well-documented and considerable beneficial effects on
the skin of postmenopausal women.[52][53] These benefits include increased
skin collagen content, skin thickness and elasticity, and skin hydration and
surface lipids.[52][53] Topical estrogen has been found to have similar
beneficial effects on the skin.[52] In addition, a study has found that
topical 2% progesterone cream significantly increases skin elasticity and
firmness and observably decreases wrinkles in peri- and postmenopausal
women.[53] Skin hydration and surface lipids, on the other hand, did not
significantly change with topical progesterone.[53] These findings suggest
that progesterone, like estrogen, also has beneficial effects on the skin, and
may be independently protective against skin aging.[53]

### Sexuality[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Progesterone&action=edit&section=10
"Edit section: Sexuality")]

#### Sex drive[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Progesterone&action=edit&section=11
"Edit section: Sex drive")]

See also: [Sexual motivation and
hormones](/wiki/Sexual_motivation_and_hormones "Sexual motivation and
hormones")

Progesterone and its [neurosteroid](/wiki/Neurosteroid "Neurosteroid") [active
metabolite](/wiki/Active_metabolite "Active metabolite")
[allopregnanolone](/wiki/Allopregnanolone "Allopregnanolone") appear to be
importantly involved in [sex drive](/wiki/Sex_drive "Sex drive") in
females.[54]

####
Homosexuality[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Progesterone&action=edit&section=12
"Edit section: Homosexuality")]

Dr. Diana Fleischman, of the [University of
Portsmouth](/wiki/University_of_Portsmouth "University of Portsmouth"), and
colleagues examined the relationship between progesterone and sexual
attitudes. Their research was published in the [Archives of Sexual
Behavior](/wiki/Archives_of_Sexual_Behavior "Archives of Sexual
Behavior").[55] They found that women who have higher levels of progesterone
are more likely to be open to the idea of engaging in sexual behaviour with
other women.[56] This pattern is particularly dramatic in men who have high
levels of progesterone.[57]

### Nervous
system[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Progesterone&action=edit&section=13 "Edit
section: Nervous system")]

Progesterone, like [pregnenolone](/wiki/Pregnenolone "Pregnenolone") and
[dehydroepiandrosterone](/wiki/Dehydroepiandrosterone
"Dehydroepiandrosterone") (DHEA), belongs to an important group of endogenous
steroids called [neurosteroids](/wiki/Neurosteroid "Neurosteroid"). It can be
metabolized within all parts of the [central nervous
system](/wiki/Central_nervous_system "Central nervous system").[58]

Neurosteroids are [neuromodulators](/wiki/Neuromodulator "Neuromodulator"),
and are [neuroprotective](/wiki/Neuroprotective "Neuroprotective"),
[neurogenic](/wiki/Neurogenic "Neurogenic"), and regulate
[neurotransmission](/wiki/Neurotransmission "Neurotransmission") and
[myelination](/wiki/Myelin "Myelin").[59] The effects of progesterone as a
neurosteroid are mediated predominantly through its interactions with non-
nuclear PRs, namely the mPRs and [PGRMC1](/wiki/PGRMC1 "PGRMC1"), as well as
certain other receptors, such as the σ1 and nACh receptors.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

### Aging[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Progesterone&action=edit&section=14 "Edit
section: Aging")]

Since most progesterone in males is created during testicular production of
[testosterone](/wiki/Testosterone "Testosterone"), and most in females by the
[ovaries](/wiki/Ovaries "Ovaries"), the shutting down (whether by natural or
chemical means), or removal, of those inevitably causes a considerable
reduction in progesterone levels. Previous concentration upon the role of
progestogens in female reproduction, when progesterone was simply considered a
"female hormone", obscured the significance of progesterone elsewhere in both
sexes.

The tendency for progesterone to have a regulatory effect, the presence of
progesterone [receptors](/wiki/Receptor_\(biochemistry\) "Receptor
\(biochemistry\)") in many types of body tissue, and the pattern of
deterioration (or [tumor](/wiki/Tumor "Tumor") formation) in many of those
increasing in later years when progesterone levels have dropped, is prompting
widespread research into the potential value of maintaining progesterone
levels in both males and females.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

### Brain damage[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Progesterone&action=edit&section=15
"Edit section: Brain damage")]

See also: [Progesterone (medication) § Brain
damage](/wiki/Progesterone_\(medication\)#Brain_damage "Progesterone
\(medication\)")

Previous studies have shown that progesterone supports the normal development
of neurons in the brain, and that the hormone has a protective effect on
damaged brain tissue. It has been observed in animal models that females have
reduced susceptibility to [traumatic brain
injury](/wiki/Traumatic_brain_injury "Traumatic brain injury") and this
protective effect has been hypothesized to be caused by increased circulating
levels of [estrogen](/wiki/Estrogen "Estrogen") and progesterone in
females.[60]

#### Proposed
mechanism[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Progesterone&action=edit&section=16 "Edit
section: Proposed mechanism")]

The mechanism of progesterone protective effects may be the reduction of
inflammation that follows brain trauma and hemorrhage.[61][62]

Damage incurred by traumatic brain injury is believed to be caused in part by
mass [depolarization](/wiki/Depolarization "Depolarization") leading to
[excitotoxicity](/wiki/Excitotoxicity "Excitotoxicity"). One way in which
progesterone helps to alleviate some of this excitotoxicity is by blocking the
[voltage-dependent calcium channels](/wiki/Voltage-dependent_calcium_channel
"Voltage-dependent calcium channel") that trigger
[neurotransmitter](/wiki/Neurotransmitter "Neurotransmitter") release.[63] It
does so by manipulating the signaling pathways of [transcription
factors](/wiki/Transcription_factor "Transcription factor") involved in this
release. Another method for reducing the excitotoxicity is by up-regulating
the [GABAA](/wiki/GABAA_receptor "GABAA receptor"), a widespread inhibitory
neurotransmitter receptor.[64]

Progesterone has also been shown to prevent [apoptosis](/wiki/Apoptosis
"Apoptosis") in neurons, a common consequence of brain injury.[65] It does so
by inhibiting enzymes involved in the apoptosis pathway specifically
concerning the mitochondria, such as activated [caspase 3](/wiki/Caspase_3
"Caspase 3") and [cytochrome c](/wiki/Cytochrome_c "Cytochrome c").

Not only does progesterone help prevent further damage, it has also been shown
to aid in [neuroregeneration](/wiki/Neuroregeneration "Neuroregeneration").
One of the serious effects of traumatic brain injury includes edema. Animal
studies show that progesterone treatment leads to a decrease in
[edema](/wiki/Edema "Edema") levels by increasing the concentration of
[macrophages](/wiki/Macrophage "Macrophage") and [microglia](/wiki/Microglia
"Microglia") sent to the injured tissue.[63][66] This was observed in the form
of reduced leakage from the [blood brain barrier](/wiki/Blood_brain_barrier
"Blood brain barrier") in secondary recovery in progesterone treated rats. In
addition, progesterone was observed to have [antioxidant](/wiki/Antioxidant
"Antioxidant") properties, reducing the concentration of [oxygen free
radicals](/wiki/Reactive_oxygen_species "Reactive oxygen species") faster than
without.[64] There is also evidence that the addition of progesterone can also
help re[myelinate](/wiki/Myelin "Myelin") damaged [axons](/wiki/Axons "Axons")
due to trauma, restoring some lost neural signal conduction.[64] Another way
progesterone aids in regeneration includes increasing the circulation of
endothelial progenitor cells in the brain.[67] This helps new
[vasculature](/wiki/Vasculature "Vasculature") to grow around scar tissue
which helps repair the area of insult.

### Addiction[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Progesterone&action=edit&section=17
"Edit section: Addiction")]

See also: [Progesterone (medication) §
Addiction](/wiki/Progesterone_\(medication\)#Addiction "Progesterone
\(medication\)")

Progesterone enhances the function of [serotonin
receptors](/wiki/Serotonin_receptor "Serotonin receptor") in the brain, so an
excess or deficit of progesterone has the potential to result in significant
neurochemical issues. This provides an explanation for why some people resort
to substances that enhance [serotonin](/wiki/Serotonin "Serotonin") activity
such as [nicotine](/wiki/Nicotine "Nicotine"), [alcohol](/wiki/Alcohol
"Alcohol"), and [cannabis](/wiki/Cannabis_\(drug\) "Cannabis \(drug\)") when
their progesterone levels fall below optimal levels.[68]

  * Sex differences in hormone levels may induce women to respond differently than men to nicotine. When women undergo cyclic changes or different hormonal transition phases (menopause, pregnancy, adolescence), there are changes in their progesterone levels.[69] Therefore, females have an increased biological vulnerability to nicotine’s reinforcing effects compared to males and progesterone may be used to counter this enhanced vulnerability. This information supports the idea that progesterone can affect behavior.[68]
  * Similar to nicotine, cocaine also increases the release of dopamine in the brain. The neurotransmitter is involved in the reward center and is one of the main neurotransmitters involved with substance abuse and reliance. In a study of cocaine users, it was reported that progesterone reduced craving and the feeling of being stimulated by cocaine. Thus, progesterone was suggested as an agent that decreases cocaine craving by reducing the dopaminergic properties of the drug.[70]

### Other
effects[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Progesterone&action=edit&section=18 "Edit
section: Other effects")]

  * Progesterone also has a role in skin elasticity and bone strength, in [respiration](/wiki/Respiration_\(physiology\) "Respiration \(physiology\)"), in nerve tissue and in [female sexuality](/wiki/Female_sexuality "Female sexuality"), and the presence of progesterone receptors in certain muscle and fat tissue may hint at a role in [sexually dimorphic](/wiki/Sexual_dimorphism "Sexual dimorphism") proportions of those.[71][_[copyright violation?](/wiki/Wikipedia:Copyrights#Linking_to_copyrighted_works "Wikipedia:Copyrights")_]
  * During pregnancy, progesterone is said to decrease irritability.[72]
  * During pregnancy, progesterone helps to suppress immune responses of the mother to fetal antigens, which prevents rejection of the fetus.[72]
  * Progesterone raises [epidermal growth factor-1](/wiki/Epidermal_growth_factor-1 "Epidermal growth factor-1") (EGF-1) levels, a factor often used to induce proliferation, and used to sustain cultures, of [stem cells](/wiki/Stem_cell "Stem cell").[73]
  * Progesterone increases core temperature (thermogenic function) during ovulation.[74]
  * Progesterone reduces [spasm](/wiki/Spasm "Spasm") and relaxes [smooth muscle](/wiki/Smooth_muscle "Smooth muscle"). [Bronchi](/wiki/Bronchi "Bronchi") are widened and [mucus](/wiki/Mucus "Mucus") regulated. (PRs are widely present in [submucosal tissue](/wiki/Mucous_membrane "Mucous membrane").)
  * Progesterone acts as an [antiinflammatory](/wiki/Inflammation "Inflammation") agent and regulates the [immune response](/wiki/Immune_response "Immune response").
  * Progesterone reduces [gall-bladder](/wiki/Gall-bladder "Gall-bladder") activity.[75]
  * Progesterone normalizes [blood](/wiki/Blood "Blood") clotting and vascular tone, [zinc](/wiki/Zinc "Zinc") and [copper](/wiki/Copper "Copper") levels, [cell](/wiki/Cell_\(biology\) "Cell \(biology\)") [oxygen](/wiki/Oxygen "Oxygen") levels, and use of fat stores for energy.
  * Progesterone may affect gum health, increasing risk of gingivitis (gum inflammation).[76]
  * Progesterone appears to prevent [endometrial cancer](/wiki/Endometrial_cancer "Endometrial cancer") (involving the uterine lining) by regulating the effects of estrogen.
  * Progesterone plays an important role in the signaling of insulin release and pancreatic function, and may affect the susceptibility to diabetes or gestational diabetes.[77][78]
  * Progesterone may play a role in male behavior, such as in male aggression towards infants.[79]

## Biochemistry[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Progesterone&action=edit&section=19
"Edit section: Biochemistry")]

### Biosynthesis[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Progesterone&action=edit&section=20
"Edit section: Biosynthesis")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/13/Steroidogenesis.svg/500px-
Steroidogenesis.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Steroidogenesis.svg)

[](/wiki/File:Steroidogenesis.svg "Enlarge")

[Steroidogenesis](/wiki/Steroidogenesis "Steroidogenesis"), showing
progesterone among the progestogens in yellow area.[80]

In mammals, progesterone, like all other [steroid](/wiki/Steroid "Steroid")
[hormones](/wiki/Hormone "Hormone"), is synthesized from
[pregnenolone](/wiki/Pregnenolone "Pregnenolone"), which itself is derived
from [cholesterol](/wiki/Cholesterol "Cholesterol").

Cholesterol undergoes double oxidation to produce [22 _R_
-hydroxycholesterol](/wiki/22R-hydroxycholesterol "22R-hydroxycholesterol")
and then [20α,22 _R_
-dihydroxycholesterol](/wiki/20%CE%B1,22R-dihydroxycholesterol
"20α,22R-dihydroxycholesterol"). This vicinal [diol](/wiki/Diol "Diol") is
then further oxidized with loss of the side chain starting at position C22 to
produce pregnenolone. This reaction is catalyzed by
[cytochrome](/wiki/Cytochrome "Cytochrome") [P450scc](/wiki/P450scc
"P450scc").

The conversion of pregnenolone to progesterone takes place in two steps.
First, the 3β-[hydroxyl](/wiki/Hydroxyl "Hydroxyl") group is oxidized to a
[keto](/wiki/Ketone "Ketone") group and second, the [double
bond](/wiki/Double_bond "Double bond") is moved to C4, from C5 through a
keto/[enol](/wiki/Enol "Enol") [tautomerization](/wiki/Tautomer "Tautomer")
reaction.[81] This reaction is catalyzed by [3β-hydroxysteroid
dehydrogenase/δ5-4-isomerase](/wiki/3%CE%B2-hydroxysteroid_dehydrogenase
"3β-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase").

Progesterone in turn is the precursor of the mineralocorticoid
[aldosterone](/wiki/Aldosterone "Aldosterone"), and after conversion to
[17α-hydroxyprogesterone](/wiki/17%CE%B1-hydroxyprogesterone
"17α-hydroxyprogesterone"), of [cortisol](/wiki/Cortisol "Cortisol") and
[androstenedione](/wiki/Androstenedione "Androstenedione"). Androstenedione
can be converted to [testosterone](/wiki/Testosterone "Testosterone"),
[estrone](/wiki/Estrone "Estrone"), and [estradiol](/wiki/Estradiol
"Estradiol").

Pregnenolone and progesterone can also be synthesized by [yeast](/wiki/Yeast
"Yeast").[82]

### Distribution[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Progesterone&action=edit&section=21
"Edit section: Distribution")]

Progesterone binds extensively to [plasma proteins](/wiki/Plasma_protein
"Plasma protein"), including [albumin](/wiki/Albumin "Albumin") (50–54%) and
[transcortin](/wiki/Transcortin "Transcortin") (43–48%).[83] It has similar
affinity for albumin relative to the PR.[13]

### Metabolism[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Progesterone&action=edit&section=22
"Edit section: Metabolism")]

The [metabolism](/wiki/Metabolism "Metabolism") of progesterone is rapid and
extensive and occurs mainly in the [liver](/wiki/Liver "Liver"),[84][85][86]
though [enzymes](/wiki/Enzyme "Enzyme") that metabolize progesterone are also
expressed widely in the [brain](/wiki/Brain "Brain"), [skin](/wiki/Skin
"Skin"), and various other
[extrahepatic](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/extrahepatic
"wikt:extrahepatic") [tissues](/wiki/Tissue_\(biology\) "Tissue
\(biology\)").[58][87] Progesterone has a [terminal half-
life](/wiki/Terminal_half-life "Terminal half-life") of only approximately 5
minutes in [circulation](/wiki/Circulatory_system "Circulatory system").[84]
The metabolism of progesterone is complex, and it may form as many as 35
different [unconjugated](/wiki/Conjugation_\(biochemistry\) "Conjugation
\(biochemistry\)") [metabolites](/wiki/Metabolite "Metabolite") when it is
ingested orally.[86][88] Progesterone is highly susceptible to enzymatic
[reduction](/wiki/Redox "Redox") via [reductases](/wiki/Reductase "Reductase")
and [hydroxysteroid dehydrogenases](/wiki/Hydroxysteroid_dehydrogenase
"Hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase") due to its [double bond](/wiki/Double_bond
"Double bond") (between the C4 and C5 positions) and its two
[ketones](/wiki/Ketone "Ketone") (at the C3 and C20 positions).[86]

The major [metabolic pathway](/wiki/Metabolic_pathway "Metabolic pathway") of
progesterone is reduction by [5α-reductase](/wiki/5%CE%B1-reductase
"5α-reductase")[58] and [5β-reductase](/wiki/5%CE%B2-reductase "5β-reductase")
into the dihydrogenated
[5α-dihydroprogesterone](/wiki/5%CE%B1-dihydroprogesterone
"5α-dihydroprogesterone") and
[5β-dihydroprogesterone](/wiki/5%CE%B2-dihydroprogesterone
"5β-dihydroprogesterone"), respectively.[85][86][89][90] This is followed by
the further reduction of these metabolites via [3α-hydroxysteroid
dehydrogenase](/wiki/3%CE%B1-hydroxysteroid_dehydrogenase "3α-hydroxysteroid
dehydrogenase") and [3β-hydroxysteroid
dehydrogenase](/wiki/3%CE%B2-hydroxysteroid_dehydrogenase "3β-hydroxysteroid
dehydrogenase") into the tetrahydrogenated
[allopregnanolone](/wiki/Allopregnanolone "Allopregnanolone"),
[pregnanolone](/wiki/Pregnanolone "Pregnanolone"),
[isopregnanolone](/wiki/Isopregnanolone "Isopregnanolone"), and
[epipregnanolone](/wiki/Epipregnanolone "Epipregnanolone").[91][85][86][89]
Subsequently, [20α-hydroxysteroid
dehydrogenase](/wiki/20%CE%B1-hydroxysteroid_dehydrogenase "20α-hydroxysteroid
dehydrogenase") and [20β-hydroxysteroid
dehydrogenase](/wiki/20%CE%B2-hydroxysteroid_dehydrogenase "20β-hydroxysteroid
dehydrogenase") reduce these metabolites to form the corresponding
hexahydrogenated [pregnanediols](/wiki/Pregnanediol "Pregnanediol") (eight
different [isomers](/wiki/Isomer "Isomer") in total),[85][90] which are then
conjugated via [glucuronidation](/wiki/Glucuronidation "Glucuronidation")
and/or [sulfation](/wiki/Sulfation "Sulfation"), released from the liver into
circulation, and [excreted](/wiki/Excretion "Excretion") by the
[kidneys](/wiki/Kidney "Kidney") into the [urine](/wiki/Urine
"Urine").[84][86] The major metabolite of progesterone in the urine is the
3α,5β,20α isomer of [pregnanediol
glucuronide](/w/index.php?title=Pregnanediol_glucuronide&action=edit&redlink=1
"Pregnanediol glucuronide \(page does not exist\)"), which has been found to
constitute 15 to 30% of an injection of progesterone.[13][92] Other
metabolites of progesterone formed by the enzymes in this pathway include
[3α-dihydroprogesterone](/wiki/3%CE%B1-dihydroprogesterone
"3α-dihydroprogesterone"),
[3β-dihydroprogesterone](/wiki/3%CE%B2-dihydroprogesterone
"3β-dihydroprogesterone"),
[20α-dihydroprogesterone](/wiki/20%CE%B1-dihydroprogesterone
"20α-dihydroprogesterone"), and
[20β-dihydroprogesterone](/w/index.php?title=20%CE%B2-dihydroprogesterone&action=edit&redlink=1
"20β-dihydroprogesterone \(page does not exist\)"), as well as various
combination products of the enzymes aside from those already
mentioned.[13][86][92][93] Progesterone can also first be
[hydroxylated](/wiki/Hydroxylation "Hydroxylation") (see below) and then
reduced.[86]

Relatively small portions of progesterone are hydroxylated via
[17α-hydroxylase](/wiki/17%CE%B1-hydroxylase "17α-hydroxylase") (CYP17A1) and
[21-hydroxylase](/wiki/21-hydroxylase "21-hydroxylase") (CYP21A2) into
[17α-hydroxyprogesterone](/wiki/17%CE%B1-hydroxyprogesterone
"17α-hydroxyprogesterone") and
[11-deoxycorticosterone](/wiki/11-deoxycorticosterone
"11-deoxycorticosterone") (21-hydroxyprogesterone), respectively,[88] and
[pregnanetriols](/wiki/Pregnanetriol "Pregnanetriol") are formed secondarily
to 17α-hydroxylation.[94][95] In addition, progesterone can be hydroxylated in
the liver by other [cytochrome P450](/wiki/Cytochrome_P450 "Cytochrome P450")
enzymes which are not steroid-specific.[96] 6β-Hydroxylation, which is
catalyzed mainly by [CYP3A4](/wiki/CYP3A4 "CYP3A4"), is the major
transformation, and is responsible for approximately 70% of cytochrome
P450-mediated progesterone metabolism.[96] Other routes include 6α-, 16α-, and
16β-hydroxylation.[86] However, treatment of women with
[ketoconazole](/wiki/Ketoconazole "Ketoconazole"), a strong CYP3A4 inhibitor,
had minimal effects on progesterone levels, producing only a slight and non-
significant increase, and this suggests that cytochrome P450 enzymes play only
a small role in progesterone metabolism.[97]

### Levels[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Progesterone&action=edit&section=23 "Edit
section: Levels")]

Person type | [Reference range for blood test](/wiki/Reference_range_for_blood_test "Reference range for blood test")  
---|---  
Lower limit | Upper limit | Unit  
Female - menstrual cycle | (see diagram below)  
Female - postmenopausal | [<](/wiki/Less_than "Less than")0.2[98] | 1[98] | [ng](/wiki/Nanogram "Nanogram")/[mL](/wiki/Millilitre "Millilitre")  
<0.6[99] | 3[99] | [nmol](/wiki/Nanomole "Nanomole")/[L](/wiki/Litre "Litre")  
Female on [oral contraceptives](/wiki/Oral_contraceptive "Oral contraceptive") | 0.34[98] | 0.92[98] | ng/mL  
1.1[99] | 2.9[99] | nmol/L  
Males [≥](/wiki/Greater_than_or_equal_to "Greater than or equal to")16 years | 0.27[98] | 0.9[98] | ng/mL  
0.86[99] | 2.9[99] | nmol/L  
Female or male 1–9 years | 0.1[98] | 4.1[98] or 4.5[98] | ng/mL  
0.3[99] | 13[99] | nmol/L  
  
In women, progesterone levels are relatively low during the preovulatory phase
of the [menstrual cycle](/wiki/Menstrual_cycle "Menstrual cycle"), rise after
[ovulation](/wiki/Ovulation "Ovulation"), and are elevated during the [luteal
phase](/wiki/Luteal_phase "Luteal phase"), as shown in diagram below.
Progesterone levels tend to be < 2 ng/ml prior to ovulation, and > 5 ng/ml
after ovulation. If [pregnancy](/wiki/Pregnancy "Pregnancy") occurs, [human
chorionic gonadotropin](/wiki/Human_chorionic_gonadotropin "Human chorionic
gonadotropin") is released maintaining the corpus luteum allowing it to
maintain levels of progesterone. Between 7–9 weeks the placenta begins to
produce progesterone in place of the corpus luteum, this process is named the
luteal-placental shift.[100]

After the luteal-placental shift progesterone levels start to rise further and
may reach 100–200 ng/ml at term. Whether a decrease in progesterone levels is
critical for the initiation of [labor](/wiki/Labor_\(childbirth\) "Labor
\(childbirth\)") has been argued and may be species-specific. After delivery
of the placenta and during lactation, progesterone levels are very low.

Progesterone levels are relatively low in children and postmenopausal
women.[101] Adult males have levels similar to those in women during the
follicular phase of the menstrual cycle.

Blood test results should always be interpreted using the reference ranges
provided by the laboratory that performed the results. Example reference
ranges are listed below.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/48/Progesterone_during_menstrual_cycle.png/900px-
Progesterone_during_menstrual_cycle.png)](/wiki/File:Progesterone_during_menstrual_cycle.png)

[](/wiki/File:Progesterone_during_menstrual_cycle.png "Enlarge")

Progesterone levels during the [menstrual cycle](/wiki/Menstrual_cycle
"Menstrual cycle").[102]  
• The ranges denoted **By biological stage** may be used in closely monitored
menstrual cycles in regard to other markers of its biological progression,
with the time scale being compressed or stretched to how much faster or
slower, respectively, the cycle progresses compared to an average cycle.  
• The ranges denoted **Inter-cycle variability** are more appropriate to use
in non-monitored cycles with only the beginning of menstruation known, but
where the woman accurately knows her average cycle lengths and time of
ovulation, and that they are somewhat averagely regular, with the time scale
being compressed or stretched to how much a woman's average cycle length is
shorter or longer, respectively, than the average of the population.  
• The ranges denoted **Inter-woman variability** are more appropriate to use
when the average cycle lengths and time of ovulation are unknown, but only the
beginning of menstruation is given.

### Sources[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Progesterone&action=edit&section=24
"Edit section: Sources")]

#### Animal[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Progesterone&action=edit&section=25
"Edit section: Animal")]

Progesterone is produced in high amounts in the [ovaries](/wiki/Ovaries
"Ovaries") (by the [corpus luteum](/wiki/Corpus_luteum "Corpus luteum")) from
the onset of [puberty](/wiki/Puberty "Puberty") to [menopause](/wiki/Menopause
"Menopause"), and is also produced in smaller amounts by the [adrenal
glands](/wiki/Adrenal_gland "Adrenal gland") after the onset of
[adrenarche](/wiki/Adrenarche "Adrenarche") in both males and females. To a
lesser extent, progesterone is produced in [nervous
tissue](/wiki/Nervous_tissue "Nervous tissue"), especially in the brain, and
in [adipose (fat) tissue](/wiki/Adipose_tissue "Adipose tissue"), as well.

During human [pregnancy](/wiki/Pregnancy "Pregnancy"), progesterone is
produced in increasingly high amounts by the ovaries and
[placenta](/wiki/Placenta "Placenta"). At first, the source is the corpus
luteum that has been "rescued" by the presence of [human chorionic
gonadotropin](/wiki/Human_chorionic_gonadotropin "Human chorionic
gonadotropin") (hCG) from the conceptus. However, after the 8th week,
production of progesterone shifts to the placenta. The placenta utilizes
maternal cholesterol as the initial substrate, and most of the produced
progesterone enters the maternal circulation, but some is picked up by the
fetal circulation and used as substrate for fetal corticosteroids. At term the
placenta produces about 250 mg progesterone per day.

An additional animal source of progesterone is milk products. After
consumption of milk products the level of bioavailable progesterone goes
up.[103]

#### Plants[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Progesterone&action=edit&section=26
"Edit section: Plants")]

In at least one plant, _[Juglans regia](/wiki/Juglans_regia "Juglans regia")_
, progesterone has been detected.[104] In addition, progesterone-like
[steroids](/wiki/Steroid "Steroid") are found in _[Dioscorea
mexicana](/wiki/Dioscorea_mexicana "Dioscorea mexicana")_. _Dioscorea
mexicana_ is a plant that is part of the [yam](/wiki/Yam_\(vegetable\) "Yam
\(vegetable\)") family native to [Mexico](/wiki/Mexico "Mexico").[105] It
contains a steroid called [diosgenin](/wiki/Diosgenin "Diosgenin") that is
taken from the plant and is converted into progesterone.[106] Diosgenin and
progesterone are also found in other _[Dioscorea](/wiki/Dioscorea
"Dioscorea")_ species, as well as in other plants that are not closely
related, such as [fenugreek](/wiki/Fenugreek "Fenugreek").

Another plant that contains substances readily convertible to progesterone is
_[Dioscorea
pseudojaponica](/w/index.php?title=Dioscorea_pseudojaponica&action=edit&redlink=1
"Dioscorea pseudojaponica \(page does not exist\)")_ native to
[Taiwan](/wiki/Taiwan "Taiwan"). Research has shown that the Taiwanese yam
contains [saponins](/wiki/Saponin "Saponin") — steroids that can be converted
to diosgenin and thence to progesterone.[107]

Many other _Dioscorea_ species of the yam family contain steroidal substances
from which progesterone can be produced. Among the more notable of these are
_[Dioscorea villosa](/wiki/Dioscorea_villosa "Dioscorea villosa")_ and
_[Dioscorea
polygonoides](/w/index.php?title=Dioscorea_polygonoides&action=edit&redlink=1
"Dioscorea polygonoides \(page does not exist\)")_. One study showed that the
_Dioscorea villosa_ contains 3.5% diosgenin.[108] _[Dioscorea
polygonoides](/w/index.php?title=Dioscorea_polygonoides&action=edit&redlink=1
"Dioscorea polygonoides \(page does not exist\)")_ has been found to contain
2.64% diosgenin as shown by [gas chromatography-mass
spectrometry](/wiki/Gas_chromatography-mass_spectrometry "Gas chromatography-
mass spectrometry").[109] Many of the _Dioscorea_ species that originate from
the yam family grow in countries that have tropical and subtropical
climates.[110]

## Medical use[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Progesterone&action=edit&section=27
"Edit section: Medical use")]

Main article: [Progesterone (medication)](/wiki/Progesterone_\(medication\)
"Progesterone \(medication\)")

Progesterone is used as a [medication](/wiki/Medication "Medication"), mainly
in [hormone replacement therapy](/wiki/Hormone_replacement_therapy "Hormone
replacement therapy").[88]

## Chemistry[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Progesterone&action=edit&section=28
"Edit section: Chemistry")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9a/Sample_of_Progesterone.jpg/175px-
Sample_of_Progesterone.jpg)](/wiki/File:Sample_of_Progesterone.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Sample_of_Progesterone.jpg "Enlarge")

A sample of progesterone.

See also: [List of neurosteroids](/wiki/List_of_neurosteroids "List of
neurosteroids")

Progesterone is a [pregnane](/wiki/Pregnane "Pregnane") (C21)
[steroid](/wiki/Steroid "Steroid") and is also known as
**pregn-4-ene-3,20-dione**. It has a [double bond](/wiki/Double_bond "Double
bond") ([4-ene](/wiki/-ene "-ene")) between the C4 and C5 positions and two
[ketone](/wiki/Ketone "Ketone") [groups](/wiki/Functional_group "Functional
group") (3,20-[dione](/wiki/Diketone "Diketone")), one at the C3 position and
the other at the C20 position.

Like all unconjugated steroid hormones, progesterone is
[lipophilic](/wiki/Lipophilic "Lipophilic") and
[hydrophobic](/wiki/Hydrophobic "Hydrophobic").

### Synthesis[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Progesterone&action=edit&section=29
"Edit section: Synthesis")]

#### Semisynthesis
1[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Progesterone&action=edit&section=30 "Edit section:
Semisynthesis 1")]

An economical [semisynthesis](/wiki/Semisynthesis "Semisynthesis") of
progesterone from the plant steroid [diosgenin](/wiki/Diosgenin "Diosgenin")
isolated from yams was developed by [Russell Marker](/wiki/Russell_Earl_Marker
"Russell Earl Marker") in 1940 for the [Parke-Davis](/wiki/Parke-Davis "Parke-
Davis") pharmaceutical company.[111] This synthesis is known as the [Marker
degradation](/wiki/Marker_degradation "Marker degradation"). Additional
semisyntheses of progesterone have also been reported starting from a variety
of steroids. For the example, [cortisone](/wiki/Cortisone "Cortisone") can be
simultaneously deoxygenated at the C-17 and C-21 position by treatment with
iodotrimethylsilane in [chloroform](/wiki/Chloroform "Chloroform") to produce
11-keto-progesterone (ketogestin), which in turn can be reduced at position-11
to yield progesterone.[112]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/22/Marker_snythesis.png/800px-
Marker_snythesis.png)](/wiki/File:Marker_snythesis.png)

[](/wiki/File:Marker_snythesis.png "Enlarge")

The Marker [semisynthesis](/wiki/Semisynthesis "Semisynthesis") of
progesterone from [diosgenin](/wiki/Diosgenin "Diosgenin").[111]

##### Semisynthesis
2[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Progesterone&action=edit&section=31 "Edit section:
Semisynthesis 2")]

Progesterone can also be made from the [stigmasterol](/wiki/Stigmasterol
"Stigmasterol") found in [soybean oil](/wiki/Soybean_oil "Soybean oil") also.
c.f. [Percy Julian](/wiki/Percy_Julian "Percy Julian").

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/Stigmasterol_to_progesterone_synthesis.png/800px-
Stigmasterol_to_progesterone_synthesis.png)](/wiki/File:Stigmasterol_to_progesterone_synthesis.png)

[](/wiki/File:Stigmasterol_to_progesterone_synthesis.png "Enlarge")

[Stigmasterol](/wiki/Stigmasterol "Stigmasterol") to progesterone
synthesis.[113][114][115][116][117]

#### Total
synthesis[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Progesterone&action=edit&section=32 "Edit
section: Total synthesis")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9b/Progesterone_Synthesis.png/450px-
Progesterone_Synthesis.png)](/wiki/File:Progesterone_Synthesis.png)

[](/wiki/File:Progesterone_Synthesis.png "Enlarge")

The Johnson total synthesis of progesterone.[118]

A [total synthesis](/wiki/Total_synthesis "Total synthesis") of progesterone
was reported in 1971 by [W.S. Johnson](/wiki/William_Summer_Johnson "William
Summer Johnson").[118] The synthesis begins with reacting the [phosphonium
salt](/wiki/Phosphonium_salt "Phosphonium salt") **_7_** with [phenyl
lithium](/wiki/Organolithium_reagent "Organolithium reagent") to produce the
[phosphonium ylide](/wiki/Phosphonium_ylide "Phosphonium ylide") **_8_**. The
ylide **_8_** is reacted with an [aldehyde](/wiki/Aldehyde "Aldehyde") to
produce the [alkene](/wiki/Alkene "Alkene") **_9_**. The [ketal](/wiki/Ketal
"Ketal") [protecting groups](/wiki/Protecting_group "Protecting group") of
**_9_** are hydrolyzed to produce the diketone **_10_** , which in turn is
cyclized to form the cyclopentenone **_11_**. The ketone of **_11_** is
reacted with methyl lithium to yield the tertiary alcohol **_12_** , which in
turn is treated with acid to produce the tertiary cation **_13_**. The key
step of the synthesis is the π-cation cyclization of **_13_** in which the B-,
C-, and D-rings of the steroid are simultaneously formed to produce **_14_**.
This step resembles the cationic cyclization reaction used in the biosynthesis
of steroids and hence is referred to as _biomimetic_. In the next step the
[enol](/wiki/Enol "Enol") [orthoester](/wiki/Orthoester "Orthoester") is
hydrolyzed to produce the ketone **_15_**. The cyclopentene A-ring is then
opened by oxidizing with ozone to produce **_16_**. Finally, the diketone
**_17_** undergoes an intramolecular [aldol
condensation](/wiki/Aldol_condensation "Aldol condensation") by treating with
aqueous potassium hydroxide to produce progesterone.[118]

## History[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Progesterone&action=edit&section=33 "Edit
section: History")]

The hormonal action of progesterone was discovered in 1929, following that of
estrogen in 1923.[13][119][120] By 1931–1932, nearly pure crystalline material
of high progestational activity had been isolated from the [corpus
luteum](/wiki/Corpus_luteum "Corpus luteum") of animals, and by 1934, pure
crystalline progesterone had been refined and obtained and the [chemical
structure](/wiki/Chemical_structure "Chemical structure") of progesterone was
determined.[13][119] This was achieved by [Adolf
Butenandt](/wiki/Adolf_Butenandt "Adolf Butenandt") at the [_Chemisches
Institut_](/wiki/Faculty_of_Chemistry,_Gda%C5%84sk_University_of_Technology
"Faculty of Chemistry, Gdańsk University of Technology") of [Technical
University](/wiki/Gda%C5%84sk_University_of_Technology "Gdańsk University of
Technology") in [Gdańsk](/wiki/Gda%C5%84sk "Gdańsk"), who extracted this new
compound from several thousand liters of [urine](/wiki/Urine "Urine").[121]

[Chemical synthesis](/wiki/Chemical_synthesis "Chemical synthesis") of
progesterone from [stigmasterol](/wiki/Stigmasterol "Stigmasterol") and
[pregnanediol](/wiki/Pregnanediol "Pregnanediol") was accomplished later that
year.[119][122] Up to this point, progesterone, known generically as corpus
luteum hormone, had been being referred to by several groups by different
names, including corporin, lutein, luteosterone, and progestin.[13][123] In
1935, at the time of the Second International Conference on the
Standardization of Sex Hormones in [London, England](/wiki/London,_England
"London, England"), a compromise was made between the groups and the name
progesterone (progestational steroidal ketone) was created.[13][124]

nq_3953_51.Answer Analysis: The answer indicates that progesterone comes from the ovaries and placenta.
nq_3953_51.Document Content Analysis: The document explains that during human pregnancy, progesterone is produced by the ovaries and placenta. Initially, the corpus luteum in the ovaries produces it, but after the 8th week, the placenta takes over. The placenta uses maternal cholesterol to produce progesterone, which enters the maternal and fetal circulations. The document also mentions other sources of progesterone, such as milk products and certain plants.

nq_3953_51.Answer Analysis: The answer lists the ovaries and placenta as the sources of progesterone during pregnancy.
nq_3953_51.Document Content Analysis: The document explains that during human pregnancy, progesterone is produced by the ovaries and placenta. Initially, the corpus luteum (rescued by hCG) is the source, but after the 8th week, production shifts to the placenta. The placenta uses maternal cholesterol to produce progesterone, with most entering maternal circulation and some used by the fetus. The document also mentions other sources of progesterone, such as milk products and certain plants, but these are not relevant to pregnancy.
